title: Since the update about two weeks ago I have trouble with Regions online banking
content:
About two weeks ago there was a simultaneous update of Window10, Firefox and Bitdefender. Since those updates my access to online bill pay has been broken. The bank is Regions, I can log on to the account, view balances and such but when going to the Bill pay section things go bad. The "Payments" page is basically blank with only the page headers and no other content (see image below). I went to an older version of Firefox on a Linux (Mint) machine and I am able to access this page, but on my three windows machines it does not work. I installed Chrome and at first got an error on that page, but today it worked! Edge also seems to work but I really don't want to use any of these other browsers.

The bank is blaming Firefox.

I have used Firefox for years and don't want to switch so I hope what ever you "updated" two weeks ago gets fixed soon as not having ready access to bill pay is a real problem.

I have turned off popup blocking, set to standard tracking protection, shut down virus defense (Bitdefender) and several other settings suggested on this site to no avail. If it makes any differences I have about 4 windows machines that link/share bookmarks and such .

Please FIX whatever you updated ASAP.
creator: msaine

title: Can popups open incognito windows when you aren't in incognito?
content:
I was on my computer browsing reddit and Twitter, when I accidentally moved my mouse to the bottom of the screen and it brought up my toolbar. I already had Firefox open so I hadnt needed to look at my toolbar all day. I noticed there was an incognito tab open for a camgirls page on a porn site. I wasn't in incognito mode and have never once used incognito.

I didn't click any bad links or anything to my knowledge since I was mostly just playing neopets and browsing my social media, not clicking any links. My husband is sleeping and I asked him if he did this on my computer and he said no and went back to sleep and I couldn't get anymore answers out of him.

I don't want to jump to conclusions if it was just a popup that I somehow did. So can a popup open an incognito window if I'm not in incognito? Or is my husband cheating on me with camgirls behind my back when I'm at work?
creator: jenevivejo613

title: Constant Tab Crashes
content:
Hey all,

I have a few customers that use Firefox and the last month everyone has experienced an issue with tabs constantly crashing. Everyone is on the latest version and there really doesn't seem to be much rhyme or reason.

I've tried: -Doing a clean install -FireFox refresh -Disabling Extensions (we only use uBlock Origin) -New Profiles

Not sure if this is normal but there's nothing in 'about:crashes' after it happens (i assumed because it's just tabs and not the browser itself).

These are all Windows 10 machines.

Any help would be greatly appreciated!
creator: jdp68

title: Sponsored content on firefox
content:
I am visiting mymother who likes to eat in a local supermarket where they have a cafe. I paid for our meal using cash and I did not use the in store wifi and did not interact with any in store services.

I get back to my mothers apartment and open firefox to do some browsing, the first thing I see is a sponsored ad for the supermarket I have just been in.

So two questions, I understand that my phone number can become visible if I interact with a local service. But no interaction took place but they still worked out who I am and where I was. How was this done?

Secondly some financial interaction has presumably taken place between firefox and whoever controls the advertising for the supermarket. So they put out some kind of call to say "this guy has just been in our supermarket and we want to hit him with some linked content" and firefox have put up there hand and said "yep we got him right here, you pay us x and we will stick a link on his opening page"

So how does that work with firefox? so they say thay are a privacy web brower but they appear to have just sold me off to a supermarket?
creator: heseltine.john

title: Accessing QuickBooks Online on Firefox
content:
To access QuickBooks Online for Business on Firefox, follow these steps:

Open Firefox: Launch the Firefox web browser on your computer.

Go to the QuickBooks Online Website: In the address bar of Firefox go to the QuickBooks Online login page.

Sign In or Create an Account: If you already have a QuickBooks Online account, enter your login credentials (username and password) and click the "Sign In" button. If you don't have an account, you can click on the "Try it free" button to create a new account.

Access Your QuickBooks Online Dashboard: Once you have logged in, you will be taken to your QuickBooks Online dashboard. From there, you can access all the features and functions of QuickBooks Online, including managing your finances, invoicing, tracking expenses, and more.

Regards, Jimmy
creator: jimmy.wick90

title: firefox scrollbar color
content:
Hi

I have a new mac mini with ventura. I am trying to transition from Chrome to Firefox and I have one single thing that is stopping me from doing that.

It is the color of the scrollbar thumb. Currently it is light grey on slightly lighter grey. Almost impossible for me to see with my older eyes.

What I've done so far is to set this to true in the firefox config:

toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets

and created the userChrome.css in the correct profile folder (from firefox troubleshooting information page)

What I want is that anytime the scrollbar displays, I want the thumb to be blue so I can see it. I've not been able to find the css to do this.

Please help me with this, Chrome has become almost unusable and I need to switch to Firefox.

thanks Nick

title: Passwords
content:
I suffered a catastrophic crash and had to replace my computer, a mac. I replaced it with another mac.

Because the older one will not boot up, I could not migrate my firefox data.

I ended up doing 'lost password' for all my sites.

There are a couple where the lost password thing hasn't worked.

It occurred to me to rename the (new computer's) logins.json file, copy the old computer's logins.json file from my external backup drive, put it in new computer's /user/library/application support/firefox, and then look in preferences, get the two passwords I want, set things back, enter these passwords into firefox again.

This did not work. In fact, now no matter which file is named logins.json, preferences says I have NO passwords stored.

I cannot find anything that tells me how to just decrypt the .json files (at least, not in a step-by-step way that I can use.)
creator: hedge1
